text: The Lost City Hydrothermal Field, discovered 700 meters beneath the Atlantic in 2000, has been venting hydrogen and methane for at least 120,000 years - its carbonate chimneys reach up to 60 meters tall and may represent conditions where life first emerged on Earth.
The Lost City Hydrothermal Field produces up to 100 times more hydrogen and methane than black smoker vents, which rely on magma heat.
Scientists recovered a record-breaking 1,268-meter-long core sample from the Lost City Hydrothermal Field in 2024 - it may provide evidence of how life first emerged on Earth.
Seahorses have a hidden kingdom - Sweetings Pond in the Bahamas contains a unique population that scientists are working to understand and protect.
The Challenger Deep in the Mariana Trench reaches 11,034 meters below sea level - the deepest known point in Earth's oceans.
The Kuril-Kamchatka Trench plunges 10,542 meters deep, making it one of the deepest oceanic trenches in the world.
The Philippine Sea contains Bakunawa deep at 10,925 meters, making it one of the deepest points in the ocean.
The Atlantic Ocean reaches 8,605 meters at its deepest point in the Milwaukee Deep of the Puerto Rico Trench.
The Indian Ocean's deepest point is 7,450 meters in the Java Trench, yet it contains the warmest ocean waters.
The Southern Ocean reaches 7,235 meters deep and surrounds Antarctica with the coldest ocean water on Earth.
The Mediterranean Sea reaches 5,267 meters at its deepest point in the Calypso Deep.
The Caribbean Sea plunges to 7,686 meters in the Cayman Trough - deeper than many oceanic trenches.
The Arctic Ocean's deepest point is 5,550 meters, yet it's the shallowest of the world's five oceans on average.
The Sulu Sea plunges to 5,576 meters and is nearly completely enclosed by islands in the Philippines.
The South China Sea reaches 5,559 meters deep and contains some of the world's busiest shipping lanes.
The Weddell Sea near Antarctica reaches 6,820 meters deep and produces some of the coldest, densest water in the world.
The Sargasso Sea reaches 7,000 meters deep and is the only sea without a coastline, bounded only by ocean currents.
The Horizon Deep in the Tonga Trench reaches 10,817 meters - the second deepest point in the ocean after Challenger Deep.
The Greenland Sea reaches 5,600 meters deep and plays a crucial role in global ocean circulation.
The Banda Sea plunges to 6,400 meters and contains some of the richest marine biodiversity in the world.
The Celebes Sea reaches 6,200 meters deep and is nearly completely enclosed by the Philippine and Indonesian archipelagos.
Tjeerd van Andel was surprised to find heaps of giant clam shells around hot springs on his first dive to the Pacific ocean floor.
More people have walked on the moon than have been to the deepest part of the ocean.
The ocean is so unexplored that we have better maps of Mars than of our own sea floor.
Coral reefs cover less than 1% of the ocean floor but support about 25% of all marine species.
The Mariana Trench is so deep that if you dropped a steel ball into it, it would take over an hour to reach the bottom.
Underwater lakes and rivers exist at the bottom of the ocean, formed from super-salty brine that's denser than seawater.
The ocean absorbs about 30% of the CO2 we produce, making it increasingly acidic and threatening marine life.
Hydrothermal vents were only discovered in 1977 and host ecosystems that don't depend on sunlight at all.
The ocean contains more historic artifacts than all the world's museums combined.
The Great Barrier Reef is the largest living structure on Earth — it can be seen from space.
The ocean produces over 50% of the world's oxygen through phytoplankton photosynthesis.
Ocean pressure at the deepest point is 1,086 bars — like having 50 jumbo jets stacked on you.
The ocean is 12,100 feet deep on average but some fish have been found at over 26,000 feet.
A cubic mile of seawater contains about 120 million tons of salt.
The Atlantic Ocean is saltier than the Pacific Ocean.
The world's largest coral reef is the Great Barrier Reef.
The world's deepest ocean is the Pacific at 36,161 feet.
The world's largest reef system spans 1,400 miles.
The world's largest tidal bore is on the Qiantang River.
Only 5% of the ocean has been explored.
The Mariana Trench is so deep that if Mount Everest were placed at its bottom, the peak would still be over a mile underwater.
The pressure at the bottom of the ocean is so intense it would crush a human body instantly — yet life thrives there.
There are underwater rivers and lakes at the bottom of the ocean, formed by dense salty water flowing along the seafloor.
A cubic mile of seawater contains about 25 pounds of gold and 45 million pounds of salt.
There are more historical artifacts in the ocean than in all museums combined.
The deepest part of the ocean is 36,000 feet down.
Black smokers are hydrothermal vents at 750°F.
White smokers are cooler hydrothermal vents.
Hydrothermal vents support life without sunlight.
Lost City is an alkaline hydrothermal field.
Cold seeps support similar ecosystems to vents.
Brine pools are underwater lakes of dense salt water.
The Mariana Trench is 36,000 feet deep.
Challenger Deep is the deepest known point.
James Cameron dove solo to Challenger Deep.
The hadal zone is below 20,000 feet.
Hadal trenches are isolated ecosystems.
The deepest point in the ocean is the Challenger Deep at 36,070 feet below sea level.
The deepest part of the ocean is the Mariana Trench, reaching depths of 36,000 feet.
